title: Union Oyster House named North America’s best landmark restaurant
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Restaurants This is the third year now that Boston's storied Union Oyster House has won an award for North America's best landmark restaurant.
Union Oyster House was named North America's best landmark restaurant.
Jessica Rinaldi/Globe Staff Another global gastronomy award has recognized a storied restaurant in Boston known for serving New England seafood for nearly two centuries.

title: Mashpee Boy Scouts carry injured woman down N.H. mountain
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Local News Brodie Perry and Jack Borowski carried the woman for two hours down to the base of the mountain.
From left, Brodie Perry and Jack Borowski.
Paul Perry Two members of the Mashpee Boy Scouts of America Troop 36 carried an injured woman down Mount Lafayette in New Hampshire over Indigenous Peoples’ Day weekend.

title: New polls show Markey leading Moulton, but Pressley could pose serious challenge
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Politics In a hypothetical three-way race, Rep.
Ayanna Pressley would narrowly edge out Sen.
Ed Markey and beat Rep.

title: A new food hall is coming to Kendall Square
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Restaurants The food hall, featuring well-known food concepts, two bars, and a Venetian-inspired cafe, is slated to open in early 2026.
A new food hall, Eastern Edge, is coming to Kendall Square in early 2026.
Eimer Design ShareSend this article to your social connections.

title: Details emerge on 13-year-old killed in e-bike crash in Stoneham
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Local News The deadly crash has spurred safety talks on Beacon Hill.

Stoneham is mourning the death of a teenage boy who died following a crash into a car on an electric dirt bike on Friday, a tragedy that has pushed lawmakers to reconsider safety rules and regulations for the increasingly popular vehicles.
A preliminary investigation by the Middlesex District Attorney’s Office and Stoneham police shows that around 4:30 p.

title: Here’s what New England ski mountains look like right now
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Skiing New England’s ski season is in full swing — and the slopes are ready for a busy holiday stretch.
A skier passes underneath HKD Snowmakers at Killington.

(Jessica Rinaldi/Globe Staff) By Annie Jonas November 25, 2025 | 2:17 PM 1 minute to read Winter has arrived in many parts of New England, and the region’s ski mountains are looking like a snow lover’s dream.

title: Delivery truck went to the wrong Linwood Street, and now a basement is filled with oil
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Local News The oil was supposed to be delivered to Linwood Street in Malden, not Medford.
A delivery truck pumped over 350 gallons of oil into the basement of a home on Linwood Street in Medford, instead of Malden, on Monday.
The 385 gallons of oil were supposed to be delivered to 48 Linwood St.

title: Review & setlist: Stevie Nicks wraps TD Garden in friendship — and iconic capes
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Concert Reviews "I just want you to know that you live in a very, very, very attractive city.
However, it is a very, very, very cold city.
" Stevie Nicks, here at Gillette Stadium in 2023, was in Boston Monday night after having to cancel a scheduled show this past August due to an injury.

title: Wu not interested in ‘bromance’ with Trump, she says after Mamdani’s White House trip
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Politics Heading into her second term, Mayor Michelle Wu is not backing down from her antagonism of the Trump administration.
Boston Mayor Michelle Wu speaks during the "No Kings" protest rally on Boston Common in October.

Craig Walker / The Boston Globe, File Boston Mayor Michelle Wu said this week that she has no interest in a friendly meet-up with President Donald Trump, unlike New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani.

title: R.I. school cancels rest of football season after players charged with assaulting special needs student
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Local News Newport School Committee plans to take up the issue at the next meeting.
Newport police have charged four teenagers in connection with the assault of a student with special needs at Rogers High School.
Police say they arrested a 17-year-old and a 14-year-old on Monday, charging both with assault.
